DADOS-GERAIS.NOME-EM-CITACOES-BIBLIOGRAFICAS: NOVAES, L. M.;Novaes, Lucas;NOVAES, LUCAS M.

RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Possui graduao em Economia pela Universidade de So Paulo (2004) e mestrado em Economia de Empresas pela Fundao Getulio Vargas - SP (2007). Ph.D. em Cincias Polticas na Universidade da Califrnia, Berkeley. Research Fellow no Institute for Advanced Study, Toulouse. Atualmente Professor Assistente (dedicao exclusiva) no Insper.

Curso de teoria dos jogos para graduao. Professor: Robert Powell
Poltica Comparada, Professor M. Steven Fish

ATUACAO-PROFISSIONAL.NOME-INSTITUICAO: Institute for Advanced Study in Toulouse

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: The Exit Trap: Gender Differences in Political Perseverance
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: This article uncovers a gap in political perseverance among women. Ample evidence demonstrate that women are discouraged from starting a career in electoral politics, however little is known if after entering a level playing field the trajectory of female candidates runs close to their male counterparts. Measures to increase the number of female candidates, such as list quotas, may not be enough to close the gender gap if women do not persist in politics long enough to gain experience and aspire to reach high offices. Brazilian data show that when an inexperienced woman and an inexperienced man loses the same open--list PR election by a margin of ten votes or less, there is only a 47\% chance that the woman will run another election, 13 p.p. less than the man's probability. Additional tests establish that quality, resources, and discrimination from elites cannot explain this deficit women face. However, examining future marital statuses shows that when female politicians win an election they are less likely to get married, an opportunity cost men do not bear.

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: NOVAES, L. M.;Novaes, Lucas;NOVAES, LUCAS M.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Edited Democracy? Evidence of Media Slant in the Coverage of Presidential Debates
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: This paper investigates if slanted news coverage can affect electoral outcomes by analyzing the case of a presidential debate news coverage. The media helps voters familiarize with candidates by covering campaign events, exposing political platforms and broadcasting debates. However media organizations are not necessarily neutral messengers. Measuring the impact of the edited coverage on electoral outcomes net of the direct effect of the debate is particularly hard as they tend to be almost simultaneously broadcast by different media outlets with varying reach across regions. We take advantage of a unique natural experiment regarding the geographical distribution of broadcaster-specific TV signal in order to disentangle the coverage effect from the debate itself. Specifically, we focus on the impact of Globos debate coverage of the 1989 Presidential election debate. Our baseline estimates using actual electoral data and survey data show that Lula lost around 1.8 percentage points in vote share due to Globos unfavorable coverage. Our contributions to the literature is twofold. First, we precisely identify the effect of one episode in which a media filter played a significant role in the outcome of a national election. Second, the case of the 1989 Presidential election is of particular interest as an environment of a non-consolidated democracy with voters that have limited electoral experience and face uncertainty regarding candidates.

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: NOVAES, L. M.;Novaes, Lucas;NOVAES, LUCAS M.

PRODUCAO-CT-DO-PROJETO.TITULO-DA-PRODUCAO-CT: Media Manipulation in Young Democracies: Evidence from the 1989 Brazilian Presidential Election

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: The Violence of Law and Order Politics: The case of Law enforcement agents in Brazil

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: NOVAES, L. M.;Novaes, Lucas;NOVAES, LUCAS M.

PRODUCAO-CT-DO-PROJETO.TITULO-DA-PRODUCAO-CT: The Violence of Law and Order Politics: The Case of Law Enforcement Agents in Brazil

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Public Rewards to Political Brokers Evidence from Local Elections in Brazil
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Conditional Cash Transfers (CCTs) innovated the delivery of public policy in the
developing world by setting rules that aim to avoid widespread practices of political
favoritism and clientelism in the selection of beneficiaries. Yet, there is little evidence
regarding the extent to which programmatic rules of implementation are met. To fill
this gap, we analyze Brazil?s Bolsa Famlia (BF), the largest CCT in the world. Rely-
ing on a novel database and a regression discontinuity design, we find that campaign
brokers whose candidate win elections by a narrow margin more frequently receive
BF transfers after the election. The effects are larger in areas where patron?client link-
ages are common, and comparable to those for Seguro Defeso, a program lacking BF?s
stringent rules of implementation. Brokers working for winning candidates also ben-
efit simultaneously from BF and Seguro Defeso, a practice prohibited under existing
legislation. This finding suggests that fraud is responsible for our findings. Together,
the evidence suggests politicians adapt to the introduction of rule?based social pro-
grams and continue to mobilize through the distribution of selective benefits.

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: NOVAES, L. M.;Novaes, Lucas;NOVAES, LUCAS M.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: We examine the impact of commodity shocks on the electoral advantage and disadvantage of Brazilian mayors. Coupling a plausibly exogenous measure of change in municipal commodity prices with a close election regression discontinuity design, we find that while increases in the price of agricultural commodities greatly enhance the probability of reelection of incumbent mayors, negative shocks place them at an incumbency disadvantage vis-a#768;-vis challengers. We also show that commodity inflation is particularly consequential in rural municipalities. Our research design helps rule out alter- native explanations pointing to differences in incumbents and challengers, diexit, or structural differences across municipalities. We also find suggestive evidence that commodity shocks influence elections through outcomes that directly impact voter welfare, such as municipal rev- enues and public goods spending. Our research qualifies pessimistic views about voter rationality, and identifies economic shocks as a previously overlooked source of incumbency effects.

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: NOVAES, L. M.;Novaes, Lucas;NOVAES, LUCAS M.

ATUACAO-PROFISSIONAL.NOME-INSTITUICAO: Insper Instituto de Ensino e Pesquisa

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: How do parties mobilize voters when they have limited access to cash resources?We argue that cash-constrained parties offer a political opportunity to religious organizations, which can provide low-cost mobilization in exchange for political power. We examine this argument in the context of Brazil, a country where the electoral power of evangelical organizations has grown rapidly in the last decades. Leveraging a reform that imposed limits on campaign spending for mayoral elections, we show that stricter limits increase the political power of parties supported by religious actors. Our findings highlight the political trade-offs of campaign spending reforms that seek to limit the role of money in politics. By restricting the role of powerful economic interests, these reforms can facilitate the political entry of societal actors with alternative sources of power

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: NOVAES, L. M.;Novaes, Lucas;NOVAES, LUCAS M.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Health professionals play a crucial role in the delivery of health care. However, they may place their ideological preferences above medical expertise. Critically, they may try to impose their ideological bias on issues such as family planning or sexually-transmitted disease prevention. In this paper, we collect political information from local health professionals in Brazil and analyze how medical procedures change for conservative doctors when their party marginally gains access to office. Our results imply that health professionals can effectively politicize public health.

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: NOVAES, L. M.;Novaes, Lucas;NOVAES, LUCAS M.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Authoritarian reversals affect the careers of existing political elites. We examine how a regime change influences the trajectories of these legacy politicians and argue that autocrats employ institutions to enable the most threatening elites to credibly relinquish oppositional aspirations. In exchange, politicians can retain political power. Using individual-level data from Brazil's last federal and state congressional elections before the 1964 right-wing coup, descriptive analysis and a regression discontinuity design reveal that prominent left-wing politicians, who are more likely to oppose the autocratic regime, tend to openly side with the regime's party. We also show that acquiescing to the autocratic regime diminishes surveillance and repression. These findings offer insights into the microfoundations of authoritarian transitions and consolidation, contributing to the literature on democratic backsliding.

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: NOVAES, L. M.;Novaes, Lucas;NOVAES, LUCAS M.
